text: hello and welcome it's great to attend
kubecon 2020 europe
my name is keith basil i work for
rancher as the vice president of edge
solutions
today i want to discuss some insights
related to the growth of kubernetes
i want to kick us off with a prediction
from 451 research
here j lyman predicts that kubernetes
standardization will happen within the
next three years
there's an old adage that says be
careful what you wish for
because you just might get it and so to
date
the 451 research prediction seems to be
holding up very well
with rancher's own k3s project we're
seeing tens of thousands of downloads
monthly as an example
as a product manager i wanted to share a
few insights into challenges
emerging in parallel with the
proliferation of kubernetes
and so we are seeing use cases where
kubernetes is running on
wind turbines we're seeing kubernetes
now being used to support the oil and
gas industry and factories are actually
turning to kubernetes to manage
assembly line applications and a lot of
the use cases that you just saw are
driven by
digital transformation so many legacy
systems are being replaced
by cloud native applications and
kubernetes and any of the greenfield
opportunities are more than likely going
to go cloud native from the beginning
but in this deployment model there's a
nuanced set of challenges embedded in
the growth of kubernetes that's quickly
coming to light
and in summary um this can be summed up
with
one customer quote that speaks to uh
the nuance here and the customer said
anything below kubernetes is overhead
for us and
after you pulled out an answer and
teased that out a bit what that meant
was that
organizations rarely have the internal
resources
to manage infrastructure below
kubernetes at scale
so on the surface this means that we may
collectively have to take on the burden
of helping
our customers out in this particular
area so if we're going to support the
prediction we need to address cluster
challenges
in three areas so heterogeneous
architecture is one broad area security
is a second and limited connectivity is
the third
so let's take a look at each one of
those the beauty of open source in an
open ecosystem
has given us basically great a great
deal of choice in our deployment options
these choices in hardware are largely
driven by a need for lower cap x i mean
you're looking at tens of thousands of
machines at at the far edge secured on
secure device onboarding and then some
specialized use cases actually require
gpu or fpga hardware to support that
particular use case so
we want to make sure that we have
kubernetes support for
that specialized hardware the second
area is security
so the state of our security posture
should always be known for systems under
management
and we think here zero trust based
approaches may do
very well because with those approaches
we can define
data we can define our communication
flows and we can
define identities used throughout the
system right
and these elements should be enforced by
policy that meets our security need
the last issue on security or the last
challenge is one of visibility so it
would be awesome if we could
figure out how to give a complete
top-down view of the security posture
of the things that we have under
management and then the last area here
is connectivity so we have very limited
connectivity in some of these
deployments
we've got what i call clusters in
transit or the data center in a van
model
where vans are actually driving out to
uh
to do work in the field and doing
compute right there in the van
and so uh these approaches typically use
a get ops driven
pool model and that seems to be a very
natural fit for managing
many clusters for example with satellite
there's
high latency and t1s are actually still
a thing we've got many retail locations
that are still connected by t1s
and we need to consider because of the
reduced bandwidth in that case
that some of our ci cd processes may
need to be optimized
to deliver smaller container images
right so that's a concern
and so i wanted to end by revisiting the
451 prediction
because standardization is actually
happening very very fast
and to continue our momentum will
require addressing architecture
security and connectivity and so we've
got quite a few open source projects on
the table to kind of get us there
and we hope to see you and work with you
upstream with those projects
and lastly i want to thank you very much
for your time and attention
and have a wonderful kubecon 2020.
